title: Ticket #2811: BOSCO Command Line Tools
description:
We want the following set of command-line tools for a BOSCO installation.

  • bosco_install
    Equivalent to condor_install --bosco

  • bosco_setenv
    Equivalent to condor.sh/csh.

  • bosco_start
    Equivalent to condor_master. Can also add periodic check in cron to respawn condor_master.

  • bosco_cluster
    • --add hostname
      Equivalent to current bosco_add_host. Should also add host to persistent list of remote machines.

    • --list
      Prints list of hosts configured with -add.

    • --remove hostname
      Removes a host previous configured with -add. Possibly should remove BOSCO files from that host.

    • --test hostname [job cnt]
      Submit 1 or more test jobs to given host and report success or failure. On failure, should print all information available about why it failed.

    • --status hostname
      Report the status of the queues on the remote host (qstat, showq, condor_q). Results are printed only if the command is successful.

  • bosco_stop
    Equivalent to condor_off -master. Can also remove cron entry added by bosco_start.

  • bosco_uninstall
    Removes all BOSCO files.
remarks:
2012-Feb-07 15:37:48 by dweitzel:
There should be some discussion on what bosco_cluster -test does.

My plan for the initial implementation is condor_submit, condor_wait, then print out the last few lines of the logfile.

2012-Feb-27 16:16:52 by marco:
I have some questions about the cluster list and bosco_cluster in general.
  1. The content of ~/.bosco/ survives across uninstalls. Is that desired?
  2. bosco_cluster --add should be idempotent: if you re-add the cluster is the same than adding it once

2012-Feb-27 16:18:37 by marco:
I'm having problems with bosco_uninstall. It may be due to the fact that ~/bosco is in NFS and I'm removing a directory where bosco_uninstall is running from 

-bash-3.2$ bosco_uninstall
Ensuring Condor is stopped...
Sending off command to condor_master.
Sent "Kill-Daemon" command for "master" to local master
Condor is now off.
Removing BOSCO installation under /share/home/marco/bosco
rm: cannot remove directory `/share/home/marco/bosco/bin': Directory not empty
Done
-bash-3.2$ cat /proc/mounts |grep home
itb1.mwt2.org:/home /share/home nfs4 rw,noatime,vers=4,rsize=1048576,wsize=1048576,namlen=255,hard,proto=tcp,port=65535,timeo=600,retrans=3,sec=sys,clientaddr=10.1.5.153,minorversion=0,local_lock=none,addr=10.1.5.106 0 0
-bash-3.2$ ls -al ~/bosco/bin/
total 12
drwxr-xr-x 2 marco mwt2 4096 Feb 27 16:02 .
drwxrwxrwx 3 marco mwt2 4096 Feb 27 16:02 ..
-rwxr-xr-x 1 marco mwt2  547 Feb 22 21:25 .nfs0000000000f605f100000003
-bash-3.2$ rm -rf ~/bosco
-bash-3.2$

2012-Feb-28 15:24:09 by jfrey:
Comments on a few points:

  • I was unsure whether bosco_uninstall should remove ~/.bosco and ~/.ssh/bosco*. It's common for programs to leave some configuration files behind when uninstalling, to be reused if later re-installed.

  • I don't think we need to worry much about people running bosco_uninstall when ~/bosco is their cwd. I doubt it'll be a common occurrence and it shouldn't be a problem when the home directory is on local disk.

2012-Feb-28 15:27:53 by jfrey:
Yesterday, Derek told me that /usr/bin/expect, which remote_gahp depends on, isn't installed by default on many linux distros. So we'll need to change remote_gahp to not use expect.

Once option is to use perl or python. I did a quick survey of linux distros and they were present on all of them. We could rewrite some or all of remote_gahp using perl or python.

2012-Mar-19 15:27:04 by marco:
I added the status option to bosco_cluster (bosco_cluster --status) and checked it into git.

It prints the status of whichever queue is available: qstat (torque), showq (maui), condor_q (condor)

2012-Mar-15 00:05   Check-in [30959]: Adding the max_queue attribute to a bosco entry's attributes. #2811 The bosco cluster will keep the max queued allowed at the site. This attribute is detected by running: $ qmgr -c 'print server' The value can be updated by running add again on an existing entry. (By Derek Weitzel )
